cuisine.description: Georgia’s food culture is famously warm and diverse, anchored in fresh local ingredients and centuries-old recipes. Signature dishes include khinkali (soup-filled meat dumplings), khachapuri (cheese-laden bread), lobio (spiced red bean stew), mtsvadi (grilled meat skewers), and pkhali (walnut-and-vegetable pâtés). Meals are social affairs epitomized by the supra, a lavish feast led by a tamada (toastmaster) where abundant plates and rounds of toasts celebrate hospitality and friendship.

wine.description: Georgia is often called the cradle of wine, with evidence of viticulture dating back to 6000 BC. Traditional qvevri winemaking (fermenting grapes in buried clay jars) remains widespread and is UNESCO-listed. The Kakheti region produces around 70% of the country’s wine, featuring robust reds like Saperavi and crisp whites such as Rkatsiteli. Visitors can enjoy both amber qvevri wines and European-style vintages, all highlighting Georgia’s ancient winemaking heritage.
